title: 'American Idol's Luke Bryan recalls 'mental torture' of singing national anthem at Super Bowl
text:
USA TODAY

Though country music star Luke Bryan spends his days judging singers on the competition series "American Idol," he said he was the one under scrutiny for his 2017 Super Bowl gig.

The "Most People are Good" crooner recalled the "mental torture" of singing the national anthem at the televised football game in a clip from "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon" published Monday.

According to Bryan, taking on such an iconic song came with unique pressures.

"You either get the anthem right or you don't," he said.

The 43-year-old added his friends didn't get the stress he was under, urging him to "do jägerbombs all night" with them before his performance.

"Hey man, we're partying tonight, come to this bar!" Bryan said his pals would tell him. "And I'm like, 'Guys, I'm performing in front of 125 million people on Sunday.' … They're like, 'Aw man, no fair. You've changed.' "

Not only did Bryan's friends try to get him to party before the big event, but the singer also said he had "eight buddies" fly to Vegas to bet on how his performance would turn out.

The friends called Bryan from Vegas to interrogate him about what he was going to wear, as well as how long the song would be, down to the second.

"They're like, 'Are you gonna be 2:12 or 2:13? I'm like, 'Guys, I don't know. I'm walking my (expletive) out there and singing the national anthem,' " he said.

Once the performance was over, however, Bryan finally got a well-earned drink.

"Literally, I get to the box after I perform the anthem, and I'm just like, 'Somebody get me a vodka drink right now, so I can get my life back on track,' " he said.

Bryan added he ended up leaving the game early, while the team he was rooting for, the Atlanta Falcons, were ahead.

"Somebody had to tell me the next morning that we lost," he said. "I was out. Then I went and did jägerbombs."

description: Luke Bryan may be tasked with judging singers on "American Idol," but he says he was the one under pressure when he sang at the Super Bowl in 2017.
